Comment: I always favour 1.e4 as my opening, because I have little experience in 1.d4.
1.e6 is common enough so that I know the main line for this, the French.
Following the main line of the French.
This move hit me like a bullet. I have never seen this move in play before. What I see way more often is 2...d5.
Although the d pawn was already protected, I protected it again with a knight while developing.
The queen comes out with check, so I have to get out of it.
I block the check with the bishop, which attacks the offending queen.
The queen moves back and attacks the b pawn
A mistake. Correct is Bc3, defending the b pawn.
Black snaps at this opportunity to take my b pawn which I had missed. With this move, black attacks my rook in the corner.
This was the only real way to get out of trouble because moving the knight to c3 would lose the knight...with check!
Black plays a move that keeps pressure on me to keep everything defended.
I am continuing development while black falls behind. I have developed all my minor pieces and ready to castle, while black only has his queen out.
Another queen move. Black should have been developing a longtime ago.
I castle kingside and feel safe because the black queen will need time to get to my king, time that black needs to use developing his pieces.
This move prepares to fianchetto black's bishop which is currently being traped by the c5 pawn.
One of the advantages I get with black taking my b2 pawn is I get the half open b file whereas black doesn't have any files to work with his rooks.
Black trades his flank pawn with my center pawn while opening the 5th rank for his queen. However, I will maintain my center control because, as stated before, I have the lead in development.
I take back with my bishop, and also force black to play f6, because 10...e5 fails to 11. Bxe5, 10...Nf6 fails to 11. Bxf6 and 10...Bg7 fails to 11.Bxg7.
The expected move. The pawn is protected by the knight on g8.
